pull_request.title: first cut adding ML-*
pull_request.body:
This is meant as a test-bed for upstream-triggered CI testing of algorithm-changing PRs such as https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/pull/1626

This PR thus replaces #344 introducing ML-KEM and ML-DSA

comment.body: Kind-of: In the absence of a spec (or can you point to one, @bhess ?) I took [the OIDs chosen by the IETF hackathon](https://github.com/IETF-Hackathon/pqc-certificates/blob/master/docs/oid_mapping.md) (assuming that's the latest ... is it, @praveksharma ?) And if they chose the same OID as for Kyber, well, that points to bad OID management (in this case apparently by the Legions of Bouncy Castle owning that range) and/or the need for someone to take the lead and draft a spec (@dstebila -- what about an "independent" PQ alliance taking that lead?)

comment.body:
Thanks for the pointer, I see two issues with the get_tmp_kem_oid() code.

https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/blob/510fea62449edb14b3ead8a51061b251817298cf/oqs-template/generate.py#L95-L98

- OIDs of unrelated algorithms change if new ones are added: e.g., frodo640aes: `1.3.9999.99.50` -> `1.3.9999.99.58`
- OID collisions: e.g., before the PR, OID `1.3.9999.99.54` was for frodo976aes, now the same OID is for `x448_bikel3`

But maybe I misunderstand the purpose of the temp KEM OIDs. If they are just dummy values not supposed to be globally unique, why not assign the same temp OID for all algorithms without specified OID?

-| p256_frodo640aes | 1.3.9999.99.49 | OQS_OID_P256_FRODO640AES

comment.body:
> why not assign the same temp OID for all algorithms without specified OID?

Such as to avoid persistent artifacts of different algorithms generated from the same `oqsprovider` version to have the same OID. This has been done to ensure hackathon events (using one `oqsprovider` version) can differentiate artifacts created.

You do have a point in that different `oqsprovider` versions can generate OID clashes "over time": This has not been considered a problem as unspecified OIDs cannot/should not be relied on "over time", though: If someone would consider this an issue, s/he is free to specify OIDs in "generate.yml" to avoid that -- but then also has to "manage" those OIDs.

comment.body:
Thanks for the background, I wasn't aware of the KEM temp OIDs for the hackathons.

> different `oqsprovider` versions can generate OID clashes "over time"

Would it be reasonable to add a warning for the KEM default OIDs to [ALGORITHMS.md](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/blob/main/ALGORITHMS.md#OIDs)? Please correct me if I'm wrong, but at least for the signatures I think we so far attempted to avoid OID clashes over time also for the "OQS-defined" OIDs. I read the [warning](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/blob/main/ALGORITHMS.md#OIDs) that "X.509 OIDs may be subject to change prior to final standardization." such as the default OIDs are non-final, but not that they might clash over time.

pull_request.body:
This is meant as a test-bed for upstream-triggered CI testing of algorithm-changing PRs such as https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/pull/1626

comment.body:
> Kind-of: In the absence of a spec (or can you point to one, @bhess ?) I took [the OIDs chosen by the IETF hackathon](https://github.com/IETF-Hackathon/pqc-certificates/blob/master/docs/oid_mapping.md) (assuming that's the latest ... is it, @praveksharma ?) And if they chose the same OID as for Kyber, well, that points to bad OID management (in this case apparently by the Legions of Bouncy Castle owning that range) and/or the need for someone to take the lead and draft a spec (@dstebila -- what about an "independent" PQ alliance taking that lead?)

I don't know who is meant to assign the permanent OID for an algorithm -- is it the inventor? the standards body? the first implementer? an alliance?  @bhess, if memory serves, IBM assigned some OIDs for earlier rounds of Kyber and Dilithium, are you planning to assign OIDs for ML-*-ipd or ML-*?

pull_request.title: first cut adding ML-*
pull_request.body:
This is meant as a test-bed for upstream-triggered CI testing of algorithm-changing PRs such as https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/pull/1626

This PR thus replaces #344 introducing ML-KEM and ML-DSA

comment.body: NIST usually registers OIDs for approved/standardized algorithms in [CSOR](https://csrc.nist.gov/projects/computer-security-objects-register/algorithm-registration). We have in the past reserved OIDs for algorithms used but not already assigned (earlier round versions and ML-DSA-ipd).

pull_request.title: first cut adding ML-*
pull_request.body:
This is meant as a test-bed for upstream-triggered CI testing of algorithm-changing PRs such as https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/pull/1626

This PR thus replaces #344 introducing ML-KEM and ML-DSA

comment.body: Why isn't this result being error checked? And why is `_acquire_lock` also not returning a status?

pull_request.title: Add Stateful Signature (XMSS and LMS)
pull_request.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
Adds implementations of stateful signatures to liboqs for XMSS and LMS. The feature include new OQS APIs to generate key-pairs, signature generation, verification, and secret key state-management. Actual secret key storage is left up to the application.

This PR also includes an enhancement to OQS SHA2 API to allow handling updates with arbitrary length buffers.

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->

<!-- Any PR adding a new feature is expected to contain a test; the test should be part of CI testing, preferably within the ".github/workflows" directory tree. Please add an explanation to the PR if/when (why) this cannot be done. -->

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [ No ] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [ Yes ] Does this PR change the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in fully supported downstream projects dependent on these, i.e., [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider) and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)
OQS provider support is a separate and forthcoming feature. This is separated because of the need to manage the stateful of secret keys.
<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->
